cit1.CITATION: As evidenced by the history of MMFs in the U.S., the growth of MMFs primarily relies on interest rate liberalization (Hassanali et al., 1996), and the development of MMFs also promotes interest rate liberalization.

cit2.CITATION: As the first step of interest rate liberalization, the U.S. Depository Institutions Deregulation Committee was established under the Monetary Control Act of 1980, with a main duty to phase out Regulation Q (Alton, 1986).

cit3.CITATION: From a perspective of risk diversification (Cook and Duffield, 1979), liquidity (Kacperczyk and Schnabl, 2013), and yields (Baily and Hanson, 2002), MMFs have advantages over the traditional bank demand deposits.

cit4.CITATION: From a perspective of risk diversification (Cook and Duffield, 1979), liquidity (Kacperczyk and Schnabl, 2013), and yields (Baily and Hanson, 2002), MMFs have advantages over the traditional bank demand deposits.

cit5.CITATION: From a perspective of risk diversification (Cook and Duffield, 1979), liquidity (Kacperczyk and Schnabl, 2013), and yields (Baily and Hanson, 2002), MMFs have advantages over the traditional bank demand deposits.

cit6.CITATION: With wire transfer payments as a competitive payment system, MMFs have developed rapidly since the 1980s (White, 1982; Maggs, 1991), with a compound annual growth rate of about 33% from 1974 to 1982.

cit7.CITATION: With wire transfer payments as a competitive payment system, MMFs have developed rapidly since the 1980s (White, 1982; Maggs, 1991), with a compound annual growth rate of about 33% from 1974 to 1982.

cit8.CITATION: In fact, MMFs have been widely considered an alternative to demand deposits (Gup, 1998; Pilloff, 1999).

cit15.SECTION: Research questions and empirical test design
cit15.CITATION: It is generally believed that, with investors' growing awareness of wealth management and their increased demands for higher market-oriented yields, MMFs have become a possible replacement for traditional demand deposits and that they will attract more demand deposits out of the traditional banking system (Hassanali et al., 1996).

cit16.CITATION: This result is consistent with Zou (2010), suggesting that demand deposits do not grow synchronously when banks grow their size.

cit17.CITATION: According to Wooldridge (2015), in a simple model when an explanatory variable that is determined simultaneously with the dependent variable, it is generally correlated with the error term, which leads to biased and inconsistent estimation in OLS.

cit18.CITATION: For example, the MMFs size almost tripled to $1.1 trillion by the end of 2017 from $368.9 billion in April 2015 (Bloomberg, 2018).
